sentence.text: He also contrived to marry several times , on one occasion to a shrewish wench who so exasperated him that he leapt upon her and gave her such a beating that she held her peace thereafter .
Donlevy ` lorded it over everybody else " and exasperated Ray Milland so much that during a fencing sequence , Milland aimed for an unpadded spot on Donlevy , managing to draw blood .
Saints , who have a rare capacity for exasperating their supporters when hopes are highest , saved their worst performance of the season for this crucial game .
It exasperated his grandmother to see this forceful spirit drifting like a rudderless boat , directed neither to work nor to leisure .
In the 1650s patriarch Nikon claimed for the Church an autonomy which exasperated Alexis I , the most pious and gentle of tsars .
When the clumsy plotting of the Queen of Scots against Elizabeth finally exasperated the English beyond endurance , Mary was beheaded at Fotheringhay .
The coughing , the rustling of the newspapers , the rasp of coat buttons on table or chair exasperated his brooding .
She might exasperate him , but she was fully as intelligent as he was and it would be as well to get to the bottom of this .
Being dependent on other people exasperates Julia .
This latest change of mind must have thoroughly exasperated Rupprecht .
On many occasions I have been exasperated by people attempting these manoeuvres who ca n't even use a harness or sail consistently in strong winds .
De Gaulle had been exasperated by what he interpreted as British perfidy .
Sometimes Dad 's relaxed approach to life exasperated David 's mother but she adored him nonetheless .
And yet , despite this , there was too much to separate the men ; they exasperated each other and yet they needed each other .
Dorman-Smith 's erratic behaviour had exasperated him already .
